titleInfo.title: Characteristics of Low-Level Wind Shear and Wind Profiler Based Alerting in Bali, Indonesia

name.namePart: Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science

mods:mods.abstract: Low-level wind shear (LLWS) is one of the most common aviation hazards in both clear and bad weather conditions. Low-level wind shear is dangerous for landing or taking off activities because it can cause the aircraft to overshoot or undershoot. The short spatial and temporal scale of the occurrence of low-level wind shears and the lack of understanding of its characteristics cause the wind shear warnings can not to be carried out optimally. Therefore, this study aims to determine the characteristics of low-level wind shear that occurs in the Bali region, especially at Ngurah Rai International Airport. This study mainly uses two years of observational data from wind profilers to determine when LLWS occurs based on reports from pilots and wind shear warnings. This data will then also be used to calculate the value of the bulk Richardson number (Rb), which will be used to determine the condition of atmospheric stability during the LLWS. Additional data in the form of weather radar data and ERA5 will also be used to identify weather phenomena that can affect LLWS events. The results showed that LLWS in the Bali region most often occurred from morning to noon and in clear weather conditions. Moreover, the leading cause of LLWS is due to the inversion layer. The blocking of momentum transfer by the inversion layer usually causes LLWS to form at a threshold value of -0.25<Rb<0.1. Changes in the value of Rb and the formation of an inversion layer affect the location of the occurrence of LLWS, where most occur above the inversion layer or above the layer with a value of Rb<0.1. The calculation of the skill score shows a good result for the POD value of 0.7, FAR 0.27, CSI 0.55, and ETS 0.43, which indicates that LLWS can mostly occur if it is followed by a decrease in Rb in the threshold value range for four minutes and a change in wind direction and speed of 5 kt for ten minutes.
